Kuwait (/kʊˈweɪt/ (listen);[6][7] Arabic: الكويت‎ al-Kuwait, Gulf Arabic pronunciation: [ɪl‿ɪkweːt] or [lɪkweːt]), officially the State of Kuwait (Arabic: دولة الكويت‎ Dawlat al-Kuwait), is a country in Western Asia
Oil reserves were discovered in commercial quantities in 1938
Kuwait is a constitutional sovereign state with a semi-democratic political system
In 1613, the town of Kuwait was founded in modern-day Kuwait City
During the Persian siege of Basra in 1775–79, Iraqi merchants took refuge in Kuwait and were partly instrumental in the expansion of Kuwait's boat-building and trading activities
Kuwait was the center of boat building in the Persian Gulf region
In the 1890s, Kuwait was threatened by the Ottoman Empire
Following the Kuwait–Najd War of 1919–20, Ibn Saud imposed a trade blockade against Kuwait from the years 1923 until 1937
The Great Depression harmed Kuwait's economy, starting in the late 1920s
Historian Hanna Batatu explains how the British threatened to take the Kurdish area and Mosul out of Iraq provided that King Faisal granted Britain control of the oil in the region
With the end of the world war, and increasing need for oil across the world, Kuwait experienced a period of prosperity driven by oil and its liberal atmosphere
In the 1960s and 1970s, Kuwait was considered by some as the most developed country in the region
In the 1960s and 1970s, Kuwait's press was described as one of the freest in the world
Kuwaiti society embraced liberal and Western attitudes throughout the 1960s and 1970s
In the early 1980s, Kuwait experienced a major economic crisis after the Souk Al-Manakh stock market crash and decrease in oil price
During the Iran–Iraq War, Kuwait supported Iraq
After the Iran–Iraq War ended, Kuwait declined an Iraqi request to forgive its US$65 billion debt
In August 1990, Iraqi forces invaded and annexed Kuwait
In March 2003, Kuwait became the springboard for the US-led invasion of Iraq
From 2001 to 2009, Kuwait had the highest Human Development Index ranking in the Arab world

The Amiri Diwan is currently developing the new Kuwait National Cultural District (KNCD), which comprises Sheikh Abdullah Al Salem Cultural Centre, Sheikh Jaber Al Ahmad Cultural Centre, Al Shaheed Park, and Al Salam Palace
Kuwaiti popular culture, in the form of theatre, radio, music, and television soap opera, flourishes and is even exported to neighboring states
Kuwaiti society is markedly more open than other Persian Gulf Arab societies
Kuwait's television drama industry tops other Persian Gulf drama industries and produces a minimum of fifteen serials annually
Kuwait is known for its home-grown tradition of theatre
Kuwait is the main centre of scenographic and theatrical training in the Persian Gulf region
Theatre in Kuwait is subsidized by the government, previously by the Ministry of Social Affairs and now by the National Council for Culture, Arts, and Letters (NCCAL)
Kuwait has the oldest modern arts movement in the Arabian Peninsula
Kuwait is home to more than 30 art galleries
The government organizes various arts festivals, including the Al Qurain Cultural Festival and Formative Arts Festival
Kuwait is the birthplace of various popular musical genres, such as sawt
The Sheikh Jaber Al-Ahmad Cultural Centre contains the largest opera house in the Middle East
Kuwait has, in recent years, produced several prominent contemporary writers such as Ismail Fahd Ismail, author of over twenty novels and numerous short story collections

The new Kuwait National Cultural District (KNCD) consists of various cultural venues including Sheikh Abdullah Al Salem Cultural Centre, Sheikh Jaber Al Ahmad Cultural Centre, Al Shaheed Park, and Al Salam Palace
Several Kuwaiti museums are devoted to Islamic art, most notably the Tareq Rajab Museums and Dar al Athar al Islamiyyah cultural centres
Sadu House is among Kuwait's most important cultural institutions
Football is the most popular sport in Kuwait
Basketball is one of the country's most popular sports
Ice hockey in Kuwait is governed by the Kuwait Ice Hockey Association
Kuwait's media is annually classified as "partly free" in the Freedom of Press survey by Freedom House
Kuwait produces more newspapers and magazines per capita than its neighbors
The state-owned Kuwait News Agency (KUNA) is the largest media house in the country
Kuwait has 15 satellite television channels, of which four are controlled by the Ministry of Information
Kuwait is a constitutional emirate with a semi-democratic political system
The Constitution of Kuwait was promulgated in 1962
The Constitution of Kuwait is considered a liberal constitution in the GCC
The National Assembly is the legislature and has oversight authority
Executive power is executed by the government
The judiciary is nominally independent of the executive and the legislature, and the Constitutional Court is charged with ruling on the conformity of laws and decrees with the constitution
Kuwaiti women outnumber men in the workforce
Political groups and parliamentary voting blocs exist, although most candidates run as independents
Kuwait follows the "civil law system" modeled after the French legal system,[203][204][205] Kuwait's legal system is largely secular
The court system in Kuwait is secular
Human rights in Kuwait has been the subject of criticism, particularly regarding foreign workers' rights
Kuwaiti activist and blogger Hamad al-Naqi, who is a Kuwaiti Shi'ite, was sentenced to 10 years in prison for "blasphemous tweets" and criticizing neighboring Saudi and Bahraini monarchs
As of 2009, 20% of the youth in juvenile centres have dyslexia, as compared to the 6% of the general population
Foreign affairs relations of Kuwait is handled at the level of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs
Before the Gulf War, Kuwait was the only "pro-Soviet" state in the Persian Gulf region
The Military of Kuwait traces its original roots to the Kuwaiti cavalrymen and infantrymen that used to protect Kuwait and its wall since the early 1900s
The Military of Kuwait consists of several joint defense forces
Kuwait is divided into six governorates
Located in the north-east corner of the Arabian Peninsula, Kuwait is one of the smallest countries in the world in terms of land area
Kuwait has nine islands, all of which, with the exception of Failaka Island, are uninhabited
Kuwait's Burgan field has a total capacity of approximately 70 billion barrels (1
The spring season in March is warm with occasional thunderstorms
In 2014 Kuwait was the fourth country in the world in term of CO2 per capita emissions after Qatar, Curaçao and Trinidad and Tobago according to the World Bank
At present, there are five protected areas in Kuwait recognized by the IUCN
More than 363 species of birds were recorded in Kuwait, 18 species of which breed in the country
Kuwait's marine and littoral ecosystems contain the bulk of the country's biodiversity heritage
Kuwait does not have any permanent rivers
Kuwait relies on water desalination as a primary source of fresh water for drinking and domestic purposes
In 1965, the Kuwaiti government commissioned the Swedish engineering company of VBB (Sweco) to develop and implement a plan for a modern water-supply system for Kuwait City
Kuwait's fresh water resources are limited to groundwater, desalinated seawater, and treated wastewater effluents
Kuwait has a petroleum-based economy, petroleum is the main export product
In the past five years, there has been a significant rise in entrepreneurship and small business start-ups in Kuwait

Kuwait is a major source of foreign economic assistance to other states through the Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic Development, an autonomous state institution created in 1961 on the pattern of international development agencies
In 2018 Kuwait enacted certain measures to regulate foreign labor
Despite its relatively small territory, Kuwait has proven crude oil reserves of 104 billion barrels, estimated to be 10% of the world's reserves
The Kuwait Investment Authority (KIA) is Kuwait's sovereign wealth fund specializing in foreign investment

Kuwait has a leading position in the financial industry in the GCC; the abyss that separates Kuwait from its Persian Gulf neighbors in terms of tourism, transport, and other measures of diversification is absent in the financial sector
The historical preeminence of Kuwait (among the Persian Gulf monarchies) in finance dates back to the founding of the National Bank of Kuwait in 1952
Kuwait has a large wealth-management industry that stands out in the region
In recent years, Kuwaiti investment companies have invested large percentages of their assets abroad, and their foreign assets have become substantially larger than their domestic assets
Kuwait has a state-funded healthcare system, which provides treatment without charge to Kuwaiti nationals
Kuwait has a growing scientific research sector
Kuwait has the highest literacy rate in the Arab world
The public school system is undergoing a revamp due to a project in conjunction with the World Bank
Tourism accounts for 1

The Amiri Diwan is currently developing the new Kuwait National Cultural District (KNCD), which comprises Sheikh Abdullah Al Salem Cultural Centre, Sheikh Jaber Al Ahmad Cultural Centre, Al Shaheed Park, and Al Salam Palace
Kuwait has an extensive and modern network of highways
The country's public transportation network consists almost entirely of bus routes
There are two airports in Kuwait
Kuwait has one of the largest shipping industries in the region
Kuwait's 2018 population was 4
Expatriates in Kuwait account for around 70% of Kuwait's total population
Most Kuwaiti citizens are Muslim; it is estimated that 60%–65% are Sunni and 35%–40% are Shias
Religion by Nationality in Kuwait (2018)[1]

Note:
– Christians from Asia in Kuwait mostly come from the Philippines, South Korea, and some from Indonesia, Malaysia, India and other countries
Kuwait's official language is Modern Standard Arabic, but its everyday usage is limited to journalism and education
Due to historical immigration, Kuwaiti Persian is used among Ajam Kuwaitis
